chunks.en: Thoughts after ten years of being DINK (Double Income No Kids)
Recently, there have been many posts about DINKs, but few middle-aged DINKs have come out to express their views, so I want to clarify some misunderstandings.
My wife and I actually like children, but being DINKs is our joint decision.
Whatever choice we make can be said to be selfish, so let me briefly explain why I am a DINK:
1. Raising children requires a lot of energy. If I put this energy into my hobbies, I will get much more happiness.
2. Raising children in China is very expensive, which affects my ability to 'lie flat' (live a minimalist life).
3. The education in schools now is too unscientific, with more and more political bias. If I were a parent, I would clash with teachers.
Next, let's analyze some of the most misunderstood points:
## Being DINKs is because they lack money; when they reach middle age and have money, they will want children.
If you have this view, it means you didn't actually want to be a DINK in the first place.
My family is not short of money now, but most of my energy and expenses are invested in hobbies.
The key issue here is whether you have hobbies to enrich your life, not money.
If you often feel bored, you will naturally want to raise a child when you see the happy moments of others raising children.
But think rationally, does raising children, which takes up a lot of fixed time, bring more happiness than hobbies like reading, writing, and painting, which allow for flexible time allocation?

The hobbies mentioned here are not entertainment. Watching short videos, surfing Weibo, traveling, eating delicious food, etc. are entertainment that almost everyone likes. Hobbies are things that require effort to improve or delve into, and they can keep people passionate and focused for a long time.

Take running as an example. Forcing yourself to run a few kilometers every day to stay healthy doesn't count as a hobby; at most, it's a good habit. But if you have a goal of finishing a full marathon within a certain time and you create a schedule and stick to it for training, that's a hobby.

This kind of goal will make you collect news and information about running everywhere, occupy a lot of thinking time, and the psychological satisfaction and physical health brought by a full marathon PB (personal best) go without saying.
## Being DINKs is equivalent to giving up a part of social relationships.
This is closely related to the hobbies mentioned in the previous point.

Most working people's social interactions are basically with colleagues and relatives. Both groups are people you cannot choose, and it is difficult to meet people who have the same values and are fun to be with.

But with hobbies, it's different. For example, my wife and I do trail running, hiking, and rock climbing. We basically meet strangers and exchange contact information at every activity. After becoming friends, they will introduce new friends to expand the circle. If we don't want to waste too much time, we have to carefully choose a few to have in-depth exchanges with.
Most importantly, these friends are people I chose, who can understand my pursuits, even have the same goals as me, and work hard alongside me.

In addition, with hobbies, you don't need too much social interaction at all. Most of the time, I like to be alone. For example, I have read hundreds of books on WeChat Reading, and marked more than two thousand movies on Douban. If I want to exchange views on books and movies, I would rather go to Douban comments.
## DINKs won't live well when they get old.
This view is actually refuted by most people's own experiences, because their non-DINK parents don't live well when they get old either.

As children, they need to leave home to work in big cities, occasionally go home for holidays, and their energies are mainly invested in their own children, making it difficult to take care of the elderly.
Let's leave aside whether the children will treat you well when you get old and talk about health and elder care.
Most people will invest the period of their lives from 30-50 years old in raising children, and their physical condition may deteriorate at 65.

Many working people around 30 years old will have diseases such as obesity, high blood pressure, high blood sugar, and lumbar disc herniation. I am currently in my forties and have not had any symptoms, mainly because I exercise a lot and get enough sleep.
It's not that more exercise will prevent you from getting sick, it just makes the probability much smaller.

chunks.en: In addition, my body fat is around 10%, I can do more than 30 pull-ups with an overhand grip, and my full marathon time is 3 hours and 10 minutes. I believe that even at 70, I will be in better physical condition than most 30-year-olds. Do I still need to worry about elder care?

Because I mainly do endurance sports and rock climbing, I don't weigh much, don't have much muscle, and look young. Many strangers mistake me for being in my twenties, which may be a major advantage of being a DINK.
## DINKs shouldn't get married.
People who hold this view don't understand what the legalization of same-sex marriage abroad is pursuing, and they certainly don't understand various struggles for equal rights.

Moreover, the legal benefits of marriage bring not only psychological security, but it is also a guarantee similar to critical illness insurance. No matter how happy you are now, you cannot guarantee that the marriage will always be stable.

In addition, marriage brings stable relationships, and many papers have confirmed the huge benefits of stable relationships for health. Various psychology books, such as 'Intimate Relationships', have also talked about this.
## Men who choose to be DINKs should get a vasectomy.
This view itself is black and white, as extreme as 'If you don't like driving, then you should cancel your driver's license'.
First of all, let me state that I understand that vasectomy will not affect my health, and I am willing to get a vasectomy, but I haven't had one because my wife won't let me.

I said before that we like children very much. If one day the government becomes as democratic and rule-of-law as in Northern Europe and Iceland, we are very likely to have children, but of course I know that the probability is smaller than winning the lottery.
Having children is a matter for two people. As long as they agree, nothing is impossible.

Well written, each argument is logically clear. You can only respect others if you respect yourself, so I think that even if these people are not DINKs, they will fully respect children. On the contrary, those who shout about family responsibility and social responsibility every day can't even give children basic respect and only treat them as their accessories, lifelong dolls, and investment targets (mostly, but not all).
DINKs are not selfish, at least they are better than parents who talk about righteousness all the time.
Every reason they have for having children is selfish.
I see some of the replies above and suddenly want to ask: what are everyone's views on homosexuality?
Is there a right answer to whether to be DINKs, get married, or prefer the same or opposite sex?
I think this is the same kind of question as whether to eat sweet or salty tofu pudding, or whether to eat sweet or salty zongzi.
Eat whatever you like!
The biggest difference with the DINK issue is that you can't regret it.
I can eat sweet tofu pudding today and switch to the salty tofu pudding party tomorrow.
But once the child is born, you can't put them back in, or it's too late or you can't have them when you get older, it's difficult to change camps.
No one has walked the other person's path, so no one can verify which path is better.
The funny thing is that some people may regret it, but they don't dare to admit that they chose the wrong path, so they desperately try to prove that their choice is the best choice.
But back to the original question: is there a right answer to this choice?
Looking at the posts these past few days, I think some people think there is a right answer, they want to prove that their choice is correct.
But I don't think so: there's no such thing as the best choice, you can't even define what's good.
Maybe there are people on both sides who will identify with this and step on me, [pretending to be neutral and rational] [which path did you take, do you regret it?]
I'm not old yet, I still have the opportunity to choose, so I can't say which path I will eventually take, and I can't say whether I will regret taking that path in the future.
But, whatever choice I make, it's none of other people's business, and it's even less the business of the national government.

Whether I reproduce and pass on my genes or not, I am paying taxes, so my opinion matters to the country; I do not care about the long-term future of the country, but I care about the present and the limited future of the country; I demand to enjoy the rights provided by the government to citizens because I fulfill the obligations that I should fulfill, and this obligation does not seem to include that I must reproduce.

Similarly, whether I want to reproduce or not is also irrelevant to the national government - I agree with most of what the original poster said, but I cannot agree with the parts about 'lying flat' and political government - and it is also irrelevant to the establishment of social relations mentioned in the previous post.
If I'm not sure I can raise a child well, then I won't have one.

Not to mention having children, I've been floating around outside for the past seven or eight years, I haven't even adopted a pet, and it wasn't until this year that I had a place to live that I had the idea of â€‹â€‹getting a pet.
If I choose to have children, it will definitely be because I am sure that I can raise the child well.
Whether to have a child or not has nothing to do with all other factors, it only has to do with that child.
Because you are worried about being unhappy and unhappy in your old age, you want to have a child just in case?
Because there are few social relationships in the second half of life and you need to build new social relationships, you have a child?
Because you are worried that raising children will affect your life too much, you don't have children?
Isn't that too selfish?!
Because you are worried that the living environment is too harsh, you dare not have children?
Isn't that too unconfident?!
Just to explain further, I don't know if you can understand what I mean by raising children.
Because my grandma's idea is that when you have children, just raise them to survive.
I can't agree with her idea.
Speaking of raising, it should be more about whether I can become a qualified parent, and whether I can raise this life into a qualified person.
Of course, it is difficult to precisely define the two 'qualified' here.
I don't think I'm qualified enough now, not to mention being a qualified parent, I don't even think I can be a qualified partner.
So I'm still choosing not to marry and not to have children for now.
If I feel qualified enough someday, and I meet a suitable partner, I may change my mind.
But it looks like there is no hope in this life.
